VOL. XVII, NO. 25.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 28, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

CLASSICAL ASSOCIATION TO MEET

PENNSYLVANIA'S RELAY RACES

THE PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTIONS

LACROSSE TEAM DOWNS LEHIGH

Seventh Annual Meeting Will Be Held
in McCoy Hall on Next Friday and Saturday.

The Varsity Four Wins Relay Race and
Breaks Record for the Distance on
Franklin Field Last Saturday.

Six Members of the Class of 1913 Are
Elected—Two City College Men
Receive Coveted Keys.

Varsity Wins at Homewood on Saturday
in an Exceedingly Scrappy Game
by a Score of 6 to 2.

The seventh annual meeting of
the Classical Association of the Atlantic States will be held in McCoy
Hall on next Friday and Saturday,
May 2 and 3. Visitors are cordially
invited to attend the meetings of
the association. The opening session will take place on Friday afternoon at 2.30 P. M. Prof. Welch of
the Administrative Committee of the
University will give an address of
welcome, to be followed •by a response by Dr. B. W. Mitchell of the
Central 'High School, Philadelphia,
president of the association. Papers
will be read by Dr. Magoffin of the
University, Prof. J. I. Bennett of
Union College, Dr. Max Radin,
Newton High School, New York,
and others.
At 7.30 P. M. on Friday the association will hold a banquet in the
Donovan Room. Anyone is free to
reserve a plate at this banquet by
notifying Prof. D. M. Robinson of
the University today and paying the
subscription price (one dollar) to
him. After"the banquet a paper will
be read by Prof. Kirby Flower
Smith of the University.
On Saturday, at 9.30 A. M., the
sessions of the association will be
continued with the readingof papers
by Prof. H. L. Ebeling of Goucher
College, Prof. Basil L. Gildersleeve
of the University,and several others.
At one o'clock the Johns Hopkins
University will give a luncheon to
the members of the association and
visitors in the Donovan Room.
Those intending to be present at this
luncheon should notify Professor
Robinson today.
The .object of the association is
to unite all persons in the Atlantic
States who are interested in the
language, the literature, the life and
the art of ancient Greece and ancient Rome, whether they are actually teaching Greek and Latin or not,
that the position of the Classics
may be strengthened in every
possible way. All interested in the
Classics are, therefore, invited to be
present at the meetings of the association and to become members.
Those who desire to join the membership are asked to notify the
secretary - treasurer, Prof. Charles
Knapp of Columbia University, to
that effect. The annual dues are
two dollars. This sum covers a subscription to the publication of the
association, The Classical W
The meetings of the association
this week are ,under the direction
and supervision of Prof. David M.
Robinson of the University.

At Franklin Field, Philadelphia,
on last Saturday afternoon, in Event
No. 30, which was kept till second before the championship relay races, Hopkins won first place

composed of Stiebel, Catlin,Groover
and Lloyd, running in the • order
named. Stiebel held his mark during several false starts, and got the
pole immediately when the gun went
off. He handed a lead of five yards

Groover gained more ground and

Horrax and Dignan accompanied

It is interesting to note that Hopkins has won for the fifth time at
the Pennsylvania relays since 1898.
From 1898 the 'Varsity team won
in four consecutive years, and there
is a lapse of time then for ten years
in which the records show no victories. In 1911 a team was sent to
Philadelphia • which failed to win.
The race on Saturday may be the
first of another period of victories
at these games.

The names of six members of
the Class of 1913 who were elected
into the P. B. K. Fraternity this
year were announced after a meeting of the P. B. K. Fraternity held
last Friday ill the Donovan Room.
Those elected were: John Sharpe
Dickinson, William Arthur Gruse,
Edward Novak, John Curlett Martin, Julian Ducker Sears and Abel
Wolman.
As usual, the City College stands
first ill the number of graduates
awarded the P. B. K. key, two men
—J. C. Martin and Abel Wolman—
having graduated from the City College in 1909. Four of the other best
known preparatory schools in Baltimore have one representative each.
J. S. Dickinson came to Hopkins
from the Latin School; J. D. Sears,
from Friends' School; E. Novak,
from the Deichmann School; and
\V. A. Gruse, from Mount St. Joseph's College. It is interesting to
notice that only one of the six men
is a member of a Flopkins athletic
team ; J. D. Sears havinc, been on
the 'Varsity lacrosse team for several years. Edward Novak, however,
is one of the best athletes at Hopkins,
and in two interclass track meets
piled up a phenomenally large number of points for his class. Although
he has taken no part in Hopkins athletics, J. C. Martin is considered one
of the most expert roller skaters and
(lancers in Baltimore.
Three of the P. B. K. men are
leaders in student activities: J. S.
Dickinson is editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER, president of the Student Council, and has been president
of the Grotius Society and chairman of two Hopkins debating
teams. Abel Wolman is secretary of
his class, and for two years has
been on the debating teams. Julian
Sears is ediapr-in-chief of the 1913
Hullabaloo. He is also the only
member of: a Hopkins .fraternity
who won a P. B. K. key.
The fact that six members of the
Class of 1913 were elected members
of the P. B. K. Fraternity shows that
in point of scholarship this class has
excelled previous classes. These
newly-elected members of the P. B.
K. Fraternity will be given a banquet by the fraternity this week,
when they will be formally received
into the fraternity.

Hopkins put a decided crimp in
Lehigh's lacrosse championship aspirations last Saturday when the
Brown and White went down to defeat by the score of 6 to 2. The
same game brought the banner a big
step • nearer the J. H. U. Trophy
Room.
That this is the case is due in
a very large measure to the superb
work of Sears between the posts.
Too much cannot be said in praise
of the wonderful exhibition of goal
keeping he put up. Times without number -Cyrus" stopped shots
from the very edge of the crease
that the severest critic could not
have blamed 11 im f or letting
through. Suffice it to say that had
Sears for two minutes "gone up in
the air," Hopkins' chances would
have been small indeed. Sutton,
too, was a tower of strength. Again
and again his stocky figure would
emerge with a rush from a mix-up,
the ball in his stick to go out of
danger, far up the field.
But if the defense saved the game,
the attack won it. Clever stickwork, quick dodges and hard shots
were the order of the day. Every
man followed the ball hard and
wherever it went a Hopkins player
was right after it.
Lehigh started with a rush and
in the first five minutes had had as
many shots. Our defence then settled down and drove the ball back
as often as it left the Lehigh territory. Meanwhile, Perkins, t h e
Brown and White goal keeper, had
made several difficult stops, but in
the last ten minutes of the first half
Knipp, La Motte and Hollyday each
managed to slip one by him. The
first half was fairly clean, but with
a 3 to o score against them the visitors started "roughing things up."
Especially after La Motte netted a
fourth goal, slugging and all sorts
of dirty playing were employed. On
several occasions men of both sides
were put out for short periods, and
once, when a Brown and White
player deliberately hit Knipp on the
head when the latter was lying flat
on the ground, the stands hissed
their disapproval. Strict refereeing
alone kept the game as clean as it
\vas.
Considering the fact that Troxell
was out of the game, the Black and
Blue team put up a remarkable exhibition of lacrosse and gave the
rooters every reason to be proud
of it.

South Atlantic Intercollegiates.

The South Atlantic intercollegiate Championships will be held this
week at Homewood. The trials will
be held on Friday at 4 P. M.; the
finals on 'Saturday at 2 P. M., preceding the Hopkins-Carlisle lacrosse
game. Virginia,Georgetown,Washington and Lee, Richmond, North
Carolina, North Carolina A. and
M. and Wake Forest have all sent
their entry lists to the committee in
charge. It is of advantage to. the
'Varsity team to have the meet in
Baltimore, because it makes possible
all entry list which will include the
whole track squad.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 28, 1913.
TIl i X MS-LETTER Board takes
pleasure in announcing the election
of Mr. John Knipp to the position
of Assistant Business Manager.
•
The Musical Clubs.

The Musical Clubs, with the last
concert of Tuesday, April 22, closed
a season which they may well review with pride. When it is considered that only an hour a week
was spent in rehearsals, and that
many members of the Glee Club
could not sing by note, the results
obtained were remarkable. In striking contrast to former years, the
clubs have not proved a sinking fund
for the much-needed cash of their
members. This almost unprecedented financial feature is a result of -the
successful policy and untiring efforts
of the management of Jack Fulton,
'12,and Leland Getz,'13. The way to
this end was far from easy. Two
trips were made involving considerable expense, viz.: Rockville and
Salisbury. But t 11 e numerous
church concerts and the concert and
dance at McCoy Hall pulled the
clubs through gloriously.
To turn from the mercenary, the
Glee Club,by leader Huntley Lloyd's
hard work, excelled in the expression and shading of its renditions;
and•the Instrumental Club, too, under the direction of Wilmer Ray,
notably increased in volume and precision. President Gillet succeeded in
greatly enlarging the membership of
the club. A strong nucleus is left
to start on next year.
The clubs were greatly helped,
also, by the solos, in which Ray
(violin), Gminder (cello) and Jacobs (mandolin) so charmed the
music-loving souls among the audiences.
At a debate last year one of the
judges was greatly impressed by the

singing of the Glee Club. After being told of the various concerts
which the clubs gave, this gentleman
expressed himself as much in favor
of such advertising of the University by these attractive, good-looking
young men. "Nothing attracts students like good-looking college activities" is the motto of Princeton
undergraduates--a motto the conscientious practice of which has
greatly increased their student body.
It is to be regretted that the contemplated trip through Western
Maryland could not be taken. The
University misses this sort of advertising, and one must not fail to
remember the advantages and pleasures derived from these trips. In the
May issue of the 1901 NEWS-LETTER
we are told that "the men are still
thinking, with sighs of regret, of the
sailing parties around Hampton
Roads—the picturesque fort, the
dances at the Chamberlain, the 'singsongs' on the boat and the occasional
little 'rough-houses.'" Why not this
attractive picture next year with a
concert at Old Point Comfort? And
let us hope that next year will see
performances at such towns and
cities as Washington, D. C., Norfolk,
Va., Winchester, Va., and Hagerstown, Md.

BALTIMORE

A Plea for More Rooters.

With another lacrosse championship in our grasp, everyone who was
not in the stands on Saturday should
join the rooters' section for the Carlisle.game. Athletes all tell us how
much cheering helps a team to win.
With one of our best attack men out,
chances looked poor on Saturday,
but the good nerve of the team and
the strong backing it received from
the students pulled a victory out of
what looked like defeat. As always,
a few men refused to cheer. If you
never yell, if you never "peerade,"
if you never show esprit de corps,
your college days are nothing.
Amend your ways before next
Saturday.
Although disagreeable, two incidents of last Saturday's rooting
must be noted.
First, when a Lehigh player, losing his head, knocked down a Hopkins man and then struck him, some
of the rooters, leaping down from
the stand, tried to swarm on the
field. Men on the spot can see to
these occurrences; it is not the duty
of the student body.
Second, when the opposing side
was penalized, a good deal of yelling went on. This is unworthy of
Johns Hopkins. Again, though
cries of "yellow," "yellow," are
sometimes irrepressible, when a man
is really hurt, as was a Lehigh player Saturday, they are brutal.

In the intercollegiate meet next
summer the Harvard tennis team
will be greatly strengthened by the
presence of two new men: R. N.
Williams, '16, who is ranked as the
•second best player in the United
States, and J. J. Armstrong, '14,
who won the Western Intercollegiate Championship last summer.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 28, 1913.
MUSICAL CLUBS SAY FAREWELL
After a Successful Season the Clubs
Give Final Concert and Disband
Until Next October.

The I usical Clubs of the University gave their final concert on last
Tuesday night at "Butts" Sutton's
Baptist Church, Calhoun street, near
Saratoga. A large and appreciative
audience was present, and it called
forth more encores probably than
any other audience to which the
clubs have performed this year.
Several strange things happened:
the trio got cold feet in the middle
of their stunt and forsook the stage;
the Glee Club caught a laughing fit
and butchered the "Chafer,' but the
audience was kindly disposed and no
missiles were hurled.
After the concert, the young ladies
of the church bestowed delicious ice
cream blocks(note the plural)on the
musicians, and an enjoyable social
half hour was spent. Meanwhile,
Manager Getz was busy distributing
dividends among the members of the
clubs, and he seemed to have very
little difficulty in getting rid of the
money.
Those who were present from
Hopkins at the concert were:
Messrs. Gillet, White, Schmeid,
Scovell, Marston, Supplee, Randall,
Donnho, Marshall, Yost, A. S.

Niles, Jr., E. H. Niles, Jacobs,
Lloyd, Barton, Getz, Sutton, Geissel,
Coblentz, Cole, Howell, Bacchus,
Weber, -Ray, Knipp, Uhler, Linthicum, Spieker, Lauchheimer and
Lynch.
The clubs have now disbanded;
and will cease from their labors until
school opens again next October.
'NE NEws-LETTER wishes to congratulate the clubs, their leaders and
their managers upon the success and
enjoyment they have had this year,
and to wish them good times in the
future.
Study of Arc Lamps.

The first meeting of the Engineering Society since the Easter holidays was held on Monday last at one
o'clock. The speaker was Mr. H. C.
Louis of the Gas and Electric Company, who is a graduate of the University. His talk was on arc lamps.
After illustrating and explaining the
various kinds of arc lights and their
mechanism in the physical laboratory, Mr. Louis took the members
to his shop, which, incidentally, is
the place where the big search-light
which sweeps the city at night is
located (on East Monument street)
and showed the working of the lights
at closer range. About fifteen minutes were spent here, after which
the members hurried back to their
"labs."

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 28, 1913.
JOHNS HOPKINS DEBATERS WIN I SCRUBS LOSE TO POLYTECHNIC

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD MEETS

THE J. H. U. ALUMNI MAGAZINE

The University Team Defeats North Carolina—Highly Delighted With Their
Reception at Chapel Hill.

The Engineers' Extra Man Disastrous to
Second Team—Hopkins Takes a
Brace in Second Half.

Suitable Penalty Discussed—Changes Effected in Present Agreement—Next
Meeting on Saturday, May 3.

Current Number Replete With Articles
of Interest by Members of the
Faculty and Others.

The distance of Chapel Hill from
Baltimore prevented the affirmative
Hopkins debating team from reaching home before Monday afternoon.
An•account of the debate with Virginia was, therefore, delayed to this
issue, although the bare fact that we
had won by a unanimous decision of
all five judges was known the Saturday evening after the debate.
. Messrs. Leo Wolman and Lindsay Rogers, both graduate students
and eligible by reason of the fact
that the other two universities debated their law school men, represented Hopkins on the affirmative at
Chapel Hill. Messrs. Dorrance and
Kanter, both law students, had the
negative for Virginia.
The debate took place in the university chapel, and there was an excellent crowd present. The Hopkins
speakers' victory was due to their
greater knowledge of the subject;
this permitting them to interpolate
rebuttal into their set speeches with
no sacrifice to continuity; to the fact
that they devoted their discussion to
general principles, rather than to details, and finally to their rebuttal
speeches, which were more effective
because the division determined
upon for the direct argument was
maintained—Mr. Wolman discussing the economics of the question,
and Mr. Rogers confining himself to
the ethical., international and legal
considerations involved in the policy
of exemption from tolls.
After the discussion the debaters
were given a banquet by the North
Carolina University literary societies. Speeches were made by nearly
everybody present. The team left
Chapel Hill Sunday morning,motoring to Durham and taking the train
there for Richmond, which, if connections had been made, would have
brought them into Washington
about midnight. This particular
"flier" of the Southern Railroad,
however, was only three hours late,
so Richmond was honored with the
team's presence for a night, and the
return was successfully negotiated
the next day.
To say that the team was delighted with its reception at Chapel Hill
is putting it mildly. Everything possible was done by the home students
and to them the thanks of the Hopkins Debating Council are due.

The first of the two games of the
scrub lacrosse team—that with the
Polytechnic Institute—was played
on Wednesdaj7 last. The high
school boys won by the score of
5 to I.
Throughout the first half the Engineers had a decided advantage,but
in the second period the play was
more even; the score for this half
being one all. The loss of the game
was due, more than to anything else,
to the poor work of the Black and
Blue mid-field defense, for Poly
•
continually had an "extra."
The first goal was made by Barrett after about four minutes of
play. He also shot the following
two. The fourth was made by
Wright, who caged the sphere a few
minutes before the end of the half.
Hopkins had very little chance to
score during this period, for Poly
had the ball almost the entire time.
The play in the second stanza was
closer. Moltz scored for the Boiler-makers about the middle of the half,
but it was not until the last minute
of play that Voshell made the scrubs'
lone goal.
Although many of the men played
well individually, Hopkins showed
a deplorable lack of team work, and,
if the scrubs expect to win this Wednesday from City College, it is up
to Captain Randall to give his men
some stiff practice.
The feature of the game from the
Poly standpoint was the splendid
goal tending of Wilson and the allaround playing of Barrett; while
for Hopkins the stars were Branham, Voshell, Hasson and Howell.
The line-up:

A meeting of the Interfraternity
Board was held on Wednesday last
in the Trophy Room. Certain suggestions as to the penalty for infractions of the rules were offered by
Leo Brady, '13, chairman of the
penalty committee. The present
penalty is not considered as satisfactory, and the members of the
Board are racking their brains to
determine a suitable one. Mr. Wm.
R. Baird, chairman of the National Interfraternity Conference in New
York, has been written to for information concerning penalties. Some
definite decision will probably be
made at the meeting on Saturday.
A radical change in the rules was
passed by the Board and ratified by
the various chapters, i. e., the reduction of the "rushing" season from
four months to two—almost cutting
the season in half. A provision was
also made to prevent any one fratenity from monopolizing all of a
freshman's available dates.
'Dissatisfaction having been expressed because of the present plan
of trying an accused fraternity by
active fraternity members alone, it
has been decided to have one alumnus representative from each chapter during a trial of a fraternity.
This provision has not been ratified
by the chapters.
As a •good deal has still to be
done, and as exams are rapidly approaching, it is urged that everyone be at the Trophy Room on Saturday morning at 9.30 o'clock sharp.

The third number of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Magazine appeared
recently. The issue is most interesting throughout.
In his opening pages the editor
makes a plea for more subscriptions,
since the magazine cannot be supported by the present meagre number of subscriptions which embraces
barely one-third of the alumni. It
should be remembered, however,
that the magazine is in its first year
and that the list of subscribers will
probably increase largely next year.
The current issue contains several
articles of interest and several illustrations.
The first article is by Dean Griffin, entitled: "The College in the
University." Dr. Griffin explains
the relations between the graduate
and undergraduate departments in
the working out of the purposes of
the University. In an article entitled "Some Engineering Problems
at Homewood," Dr. J. B. Whitehead and Mr. C. L. Reeder, consulting engineers for the Homewood
Committee, discuss constructional
problems in building the new University plant. Special attention is
given to describing the heating and
lighting arrangements to be made.
An article of unusual interest is a
reprint of an address made at the
Alumni Associatiori dinner on February 22, by Mr. Omar F. Hershey,
of the Baltimore bar, entitled "The
University and the City." Mr.
Hershey is not a Johns Hopkins
man, consequently his criticisms
have especial interest and importance to Johns Hopkins men. Besides the other articles, there are the
usual departments devoted to the
"University," the Medical School,
and the undergraduates. In this section is a photograph of the portrait
of Prof. William Bullock Clark, of
geology, recently presented to the
University.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSIMY
VOL. XVII, NO. 25.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 28, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

CLASSICAL ASSOCIATION TO MEET

PENNSYLVANIA'S RELAY RACES

THE PHI BETA KAPPA ELECTIONS

LACROSSE TEAM DOWNS LEHIGH

Seventh Annual Meeting Will Be Held
in McCoy Hall on Next Friday and Saturday.

The Varsity Four Wins Relay Race and
Breaks Record for the Distance on
Franklin Field Last Saturday.

Six Members of the Class of 1913 Are
Elected—Two City College Men
Receive Coveted Keys.

Varsity Wins at Homewood on Saturday
in an Exceedingly Scrappy Game
by a Score of 6 to 2.

The seventh annual meeting of
the Classical Association of the Atlantic States will be held in McCoy
Hall on next Friday and Saturday,
May 2 and 3. Visitors are cordially
invited to attend the meetings of
the association. The opening session will take place on Friday afternoon at 2.30 P. M. Prof. Welch of
the Administrative Committee of the
University will give an address of
welcome, to be followed •by a response by Dr. B. W. Mitchell of the
Central 'High School, Philadelphia,
president of the association. Papers
will be read by Dr. Magoffin of the
University, Prof. J. I. Bennett of
Union College, Dr. Max Radin,
Newton High School, New York,
and others.
At 7.30 P. M. on Friday the association will hold a banquet in the
Donovan Room. Anyone is free to
reserve a plate at this banquet by
notifying Prof. D. M. Robinson of
the University today and paying the
subscription price (one dollar) to
him. After"the banquet a paper will
be read by Prof. Kirby Flower
Smith of the University.
On Saturday, at 9.30 A. M., the
sessions of the association will be
continued with the readingof papers
by Prof. H. L. Ebeling of Goucher
College, Prof. Basil L. Gildersleeve
of the University,and several others.
At one o'clock the Johns Hopkins
University will give a luncheon to
the members of the association and
visitors in the Donovan Room.
Those intending to be present at this
luncheon should notify Professor
Robinson today.
The .object of the association is
to unite all persons in the Atlantic
States who are interested in the
language, the literature, the life and
the art of ancient Greece and ancient Rome, whether they are actually teaching Greek and Latin or not,
that the position of the Classics
may be strengthened in every
possible way. All interested in the
Classics are, therefore, invited to be
present at the meetings of the association and to become members.
Those who desire to join the membership are asked to notify the
secretary - treasurer, Prof. Charles
Knapp of Columbia University, to
that effect. The annual dues are
two dollars. This sum covers a subscription to the publication of the
association, The Classical W
The meetings of the association
this week are ,under the direction
and supervision of Prof. David M.
Robinson of the University.

At Franklin Field, Philadelphia,
on last Saturday afternoon, in Event
No. 30, which was kept till second before the championship relay races, Hopkins won first place
5 seconds, breaking
in 3 minutes 30/

equalled in 1912 at the South Atlantic Intercollegiates. The team was
composed of Stiebel, Catlin,Groover
and Lloyd, running in the • order
named. Stiebel held his mark during several false starts, and got the
pole immediately when the gun went
off. He handed a lead of five yards
to Catlin, who, in turn, increased
it when Groover was touched off.
Groover gained more ground and
when Lloyd broke the tape Ile was
twenty yards ahead of Haverford ;
Lafayette, third; New York University, fourth.
Horrax and Dignan accompanied
the team for the field events. Horrax took a tumble in the 120-yards
hurdles in the first heat.when he was
in the lead. This eliminated him
from further competition in a race
which might have been his. The
final heat was won by Crouley of
5 seconds. Hor/

rax won

with a throw of 44 feet in the shot
put, yet the calibre of the contestants
was so high that this did not place
him. He was fifth.
It is interesting to note that Hopkins has won for the fifth time at
the Pennsylvania relays since 1898.
From 1898 the 'Varsity team won
in four consecutive years, and there
is a lapse of time then for ten years
in which the records show no victories. In 1911 a team was sent to
Philadelphia • which failed to win.
The race on Saturday may be the
first of another period of victories
at these games.

The names of six members of
the Class of 1913 who were elected
into the P. B. K. Fraternity this
year were announced after a meeting of the P. B. K. Fraternity held
last Friday ill the Donovan Room.
Those elected were: John Sharpe
Dickinson, William Arthur Gruse,
Edward Novak, John Curlett Martin, Julian Ducker Sears and Abel
Wolman.
As usual, the City College stands
first ill the number of graduates
awarded the P. B. K. key, two men
—J. C. Martin and Abel Wolman—
having graduated from the City College in 1909. Four of the other best
known preparatory schools in Baltimore have one representative each.
J. S. Dickinson came to Hopkins
from the Latin School; J. D. Sears,
from Friends' School; E. Novak,
from the Deichmann School; and
\V. A. Gruse, from Mount St. Joseph's College. It is interesting to
notice that only one of the six men
is a member of a Flopkins athletic
team ; J. D. Sears havinc, been on
the 'Varsity lacrosse team for several years. Edward Novak, however,
is one of the best athletes at Hopkins,
and in two interclass track meets
piled up a phenomenally large number of points for his class. Although
he has taken no part in Hopkins athletics, J. C. Martin is considered one
of the most expert roller skaters and
(lancers in Baltimore.
Three of the P. B. K. men are
leaders in student activities: J. S.
Dickinson is editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER, president of the Student Council, and has been president
of the Grotius Society and chairman of two Hopkins debating
teams. Abel Wolman is secretary of
his class, and for two years has
been on the debating teams. Julian
Sears is ediapr-in-chief of the 1913
Hullabaloo. He is also the only
member of: a Hopkins .fraternity
who won a P. B. K. key.
The fact that six members of the
Class of 1913 were elected members
of the P. B. K. Fraternity shows that
in point of scholarship this class has
excelled previous classes. These
newly-elected members of the P. B.
K. Fraternity will be given a banquet by the fraternity this week,
when they will be formally received
into the fraternity.

Hopkins put a decided crimp in
Lehigh's lacrosse championship aspirations last Saturday when the
Brown and White went down to defeat by the score of 6 to 2. The
same game brought the banner a big
step • nearer the J. H. U. Trophy
Room.
That this is the case is due in
a very large measure to the superb
work of Sears between the posts.
Too much cannot be said in praise
of the wonderful exhibition of goal
keeping he put up. Times without number -Cyrus" stopped shots
from the very edge of the crease
that the severest critic could not
have blamed 11 im f or letting
through. Suffice it to say that had
Sears for two minutes "gone up in
the air," Hopkins' chances would
have been small indeed. Sutton,
too, was a tower of strength. Again
and again his stocky figure would
emerge with a rush from a mix-up,
the ball in his stick to go out of
danger, far up the field.
But if the defense saved the game,
the attack won it. Clever stickwork, quick dodges and hard shots
were the order of the day. Every
man followed the ball hard and
wherever it went a Hopkins player
was right after it.
Lehigh started with a rush and
in the first five minutes had had as
many shots. Our defence then settled down and drove the ball back
as often as it left the Lehigh territory. Meanwhile, Perkins, t h e
Brown and White goal keeper, had
made several difficult stops, but in
the last ten minutes of the first half
Knipp, La Motte and Hollyday each
managed to slip one by him. The
first half was fairly clean, but with
a 3 to o score against them the visitors started "roughing things up."
Especially after La Motte netted a
fourth goal, slugging and all sorts
of dirty playing were employed. On
several occasions men of both sides
were put out for short periods, and
once, when a Brown and White
player deliberately hit Knipp on the
head when the latter was lying flat
on the ground, the stands hissed
their disapproval. Strict refereeing
alone kept the game as clean as it
\vas.
Considering the fact that Troxell
was out of the game, the Black and
Blue team put up a remarkable exhibition of lacrosse and gave the
rooters every reason to be proud
of it.

South Atlantic Intercollegiates.

The South Atlantic intercollegiate Championships will be held this
week at Homewood. The trials will
be held on Friday at 4 P. M.; the
finals on 'Saturday at 2 P. M., preceding the Hopkins-Carlisle lacrosse
game. Virginia,Georgetown,Washington and Lee, Richmond, North
Carolina, North Carolina A. and
M. and Wake Forest have all sent
their entry lists to the committee in
charge. It is of advantage to. the
'Varsity team to have the meet in
Baltimore, because it makes possible
all entry list which will include the
whole track squad.

The Musical Clubs.

The Musical Clubs, with the last
concert of Tuesday, April 22, closed
a season which they may well review with pride. When it is considered that only an hour a week
was spent in rehearsals, and that
many members of the Glee Club
could not sing by note, the results
obtained were remarkable. In striking contrast to former years, the
clubs have not proved a sinking fund
for the much-needed cash of their
members. This almost unprecedented financial feature is a result of -the
successful policy and untiring efforts
of the management of Jack Fulton,
'12,and Leland Getz,'13. The way to
this end was far from easy. Two
trips were made involving considerable expense, viz.: Rockville and
Salisbury. But t 11 e numerous
church concerts and the concert and
dance at McCoy Hall pulled the
clubs through gloriously.
To turn from the mercenary, the
Glee Club,by leader Huntley Lloyd's
hard work, excelled in the expression and shading of its renditions;
and•the Instrumental Club, too, under the direction of Wilmer Ray,
notably increased in volume and precision. President Gillet succeeded in
greatly enlarging the membership of
the club. A strong nucleus is left
to start on next year.
The clubs were greatly helped,
also, by the solos, in which Ray
(violin), Gminder (cello) and Jacobs (mandolin) so charmed the
music-loving souls among the audiences.
At a debate last year one of the
judges was greatly impressed by the

singing of the Glee Club. After being told of the various concerts
which the clubs gave, this gentleman
expressed himself as much in favor
of such advertising of the University by these attractive, good-looking
young men. "Nothing attracts students like good-looking college activities" is the motto of Princeton
undergraduates--a motto the conscientious practice of which has
greatly increased their student body.
It is to be regretted that the contemplated trip through Western
Maryland could not be taken. The
University misses this sort of advertising, and one must not fail to
remember the advantages and pleasures derived from these trips. In the
May issue of the 1901 NEWS-LETTER
we are told that "the men are still
thinking, with sighs of regret, of the
sailing parties around Hampton
Roads—the picturesque fort, the
dances at the Chamberlain, the 'singsongs' on the boat and the occasional
little 'rough-houses.'" Why not this
attractive picture next year with a
concert at Old Point Comfort? And
let us hope that next year will see
performances at such towns and
cities as Washington, D. C., Norfolk,
Va., Winchester, Va., and Hagerstown, Md.

BALTIMORE

A Plea for More Rooters.

With another lacrosse championship in our grasp, everyone who was
not in the stands on Saturday should
join the rooters' section for the Carlisle.game. Athletes all tell us how
much cheering helps a team to win.
With one of our best attack men out,
chances looked poor on Saturday,
but the good nerve of the team and
the strong backing it received from
the students pulled a victory out of
what looked like defeat. As always,
a few men refused to cheer. If you
never yell, if you never "peerade,"
if you never show esprit de corps,
your college days are nothing.
Amend your ways before next
Saturday.
Although disagreeable, two incidents of last Saturday's rooting
must be noted.
First, when a Lehigh player, losing his head, knocked down a Hopkins man and then struck him, some
of the rooters, leaping down from
the stand, tried to swarm on the
field. Men on the spot can see to
these occurrences; it is not the duty
of the student body.
Second, when the opposing side
was penalized, a good deal of yelling went on. This is unworthy of
Johns Hopkins. Again, though
cries of "yellow," "yellow," are
sometimes irrepressible, when a man
is really hurt, as was a Lehigh player Saturday, they are brutal.

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 28, 1913.
MUSICAL CLUBS SAY FAREWELL
After a Successful Season the Clubs
Give Final Concert and Disband
Until Next October.

The I usical Clubs of the University gave their final concert on last
Tuesday night at "Butts" Sutton's
Baptist Church, Calhoun street, near
Saratoga. A large and appreciative
audience was present, and it called
forth more encores probably than
any other audience to which the
clubs have performed this year.
Several strange things happened:
the trio got cold feet in the middle
of their stunt and forsook the stage;
the Glee Club caught a laughing fit
and butchered the "Chafer,' but the
audience was kindly disposed and no
missiles were hurled.
After the concert, the young ladies
of the church bestowed delicious ice
cream blocks(note the plural)on the
musicians, and an enjoyable social
half hour was spent. Meanwhile,
Manager Getz was busy distributing
dividends among the members of the
clubs, and he seemed to have very
little difficulty in getting rid of the
money.
Those who were present from
Hopkins at the concert were:
Messrs. Gillet, White, Schmeid,
Scovell, Marston, Supplee, Randall,
Donnho, Marshall, Yost, A. S.

Niles, Jr., E. H. Niles, Jacobs,
Lloyd, Barton, Getz, Sutton, Geissel,
Coblentz, Cole, Howell, Bacchus,
Weber, -Ray, Knipp, Uhler, Linthicum, Spieker, Lauchheimer and
Lynch.
The clubs have now disbanded;
and will cease from their labors until
school opens again next October.
'NE NEws-LETTER wishes to congratulate the clubs, their leaders and
their managers upon the success and
enjoyment they have had this year,
and to wish them good times in the
future.
Study of Arc Lamps.

The first meeting of the Engineering Society since the Easter holidays was held on Monday last at one
o'clock. The speaker was Mr. H. C.
Louis of the Gas and Electric Company, who is a graduate of the University. His talk was on arc lamps.
After illustrating and explaining the
various kinds of arc lights and their
mechanism in the physical laboratory, Mr. Louis took the members
to his shop, which, incidentally, is
the place where the big search-light
which sweeps the city at night is
located (on East Monument street)
and showed the working of the lights
at closer range. About fifteen minutes were spent here, after which
the members hurried back to their
"labs."

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 28, 1913.
JOHNS HOPKINS DEBATERS WIN I SCRUBS LOSE TO POLYTECHNIC

INTERFRATERNITY BOARD MEETS

THE J. H. U. ALUMNI MAGAZINE

The University Team Defeats North Carolina—Highly Delighted With Their
Reception at Chapel Hill.

The Engineers' Extra Man Disastrous to
Second Team—Hopkins Takes a
Brace in Second Half.

Suitable Penalty Discussed—Changes Effected in Present Agreement—Next
Meeting on Saturday, May 3.

Current Number Replete With Articles
of Interest by Members of the
Faculty and Others.

The distance of Chapel Hill from
Baltimore prevented the affirmative
Hopkins debating team from reaching home before Monday afternoon.
An•account of the debate with Virginia was, therefore, delayed to this
issue, although the bare fact that we
had won by a unanimous decision of
all five judges was known the Saturday evening after the debate.
. Messrs. Leo Wolman and Lindsay Rogers, both graduate students
and eligible by reason of the fact
that the other two universities debated their law school men, represented Hopkins on the affirmative at
Chapel Hill. Messrs. Dorrance and
Kanter, both law students, had the
negative for Virginia.
The debate took place in the university chapel, and there was an excellent crowd present. The Hopkins
speakers' victory was due to their
greater knowledge of the subject;
this permitting them to interpolate
rebuttal into their set speeches with
no sacrifice to continuity; to the fact
that they devoted their discussion to
general principles, rather than to details, and finally to their rebuttal
speeches, which were more effective
because the division determined
upon for the direct argument was
maintained—Mr. Wolman discussing the economics of the question,
and Mr. Rogers confining himself to
the ethical., international and legal
considerations involved in the policy
of exemption from tolls.
After the discussion the debaters
were given a banquet by the North
Carolina University literary societies. Speeches were made by nearly
everybody present. The team left
Chapel Hill Sunday morning,motoring to Durham and taking the train
there for Richmond, which, if connections had been made, would have
brought them into Washington
about midnight. This particular
"flier" of the Southern Railroad,
however, was only three hours late,
so Richmond was honored with the
team's presence for a night, and the
return was successfully negotiated
the next day.
To say that the team was delighted with its reception at Chapel Hill
is putting it mildly. Everything possible was done by the home students
and to them the thanks of the Hopkins Debating Council are due.

The first of the two games of the
scrub lacrosse team—that with the
Polytechnic Institute—was played
on Wednesdaj7 last. The high
school boys won by the score of
5 to I.
Throughout the first half the Engineers had a decided advantage,but
in the second period the play was
more even; the score for this half
being one all. The loss of the game
was due, more than to anything else,
to the poor work of the Black and
Blue mid-field defense, for Poly
•
continually had an "extra."
The first goal was made by Barrett after about four minutes of
play. He also shot the following
two. The fourth was made by
Wright, who caged the sphere a few
minutes before the end of the half.
Hopkins had very little chance to
score during this period, for Poly
had the ball almost the entire time.
The play in the second stanza was
closer. Moltz scored for the Boiler-makers about the middle of the half,
but it was not until the last minute
of play that Voshell made the scrubs'
lone goal.
Although many of the men played
well individually, Hopkins showed
a deplorable lack of team work, and,
if the scrubs expect to win this Wednesday from City College, it is up
to Captain Randall to give his men
some stiff practice.
The feature of the game from the
Poly standpoint was the splendid
goal tending of Wilson and the allaround playing of Barrett; while
for Hopkins the stars were Branham, Voshell, Hasson and Howell.
The line-up:

A meeting of the Interfraternity
Board was held on Wednesday last
in the Trophy Room. Certain suggestions as to the penalty for infractions of the rules were offered by
Leo Brady, '13, chairman of the
penalty committee. The present
penalty is not considered as satisfactory, and the members of the
Board are racking their brains to
determine a suitable one. Mr. Wm.
R. Baird, chairman of the National Interfraternity Conference in New
York, has been written to for information concerning penalties. Some
definite decision will probably be
made at the meeting on Saturday.
A radical change in the rules was
passed by the Board and ratified by
the various chapters, i. e., the reduction of the "rushing" season from
four months to two—almost cutting
the season in half. A provision was
also made to prevent any one fratenity from monopolizing all of a
freshman's available dates.
'Dissatisfaction having been expressed because of the present plan
of trying an accused fraternity by
active fraternity members alone, it
has been decided to have one alumnus representative from each chapter during a trial of a fraternity.
This provision has not been ratified
by the chapters.
As a •good deal has still to be
done, and as exams are rapidly approaching, it is urged that everyone be at the Trophy Room on Saturday morning at 9.30 o'clock sharp.

The third number of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Magazine appeared
recently. The issue is most interesting throughout.
In his opening pages the editor
makes a plea for more subscriptions,
since the magazine cannot be supported by the present meagre number of subscriptions which embraces
barely one-third of the alumni. It
should be remembered, however,
that the magazine is in its first year
and that the list of subscribers will
probably increase largely next year.
The current issue contains several
articles of interest and several illustrations.
The first article is by Dean Griffin, entitled: "The College in the
University." Dr. Griffin explains
the relations between the graduate
and undergraduate departments in
the working out of the purposes of
the University. In an article entitled "Some Engineering Problems
at Homewood," Dr. J. B. Whitehead and Mr. C. L. Reeder, consulting engineers for the Homewood
Committee, discuss constructional
problems in building the new University plant. Special attention is
given to describing the heating and
lighting arrangements to be made.
An article of unusual interest is a
reprint of an address made at the
Alumni Associatiori dinner on February 22, by Mr. Omar F. Hershey,
of the Baltimore bar, entitled "The
University and the City." Mr.
Hershey is not a Johns Hopkins
man, consequently his criticisms
have especial interest and importance to Johns Hopkins men. Besides the other articles, there are the
usual departments devoted to the
"University," the Medical School,
and the undergraduates. In this section is a photograph of the portrait
of Prof. William Bullock Clark, of
geology, recently presented to the
University.
